title: 105_hr3662
content: The Act titled "U.S. Holocaust Assets Commission Act of 1998" establishes a commission. The "U.S. Holocaust Assets Commission Act of 1998" establishes the Presidential Advisory Commission on Holocaust Assets in the United States, composed of 19 members appointed by the President, including private citizens, representatives of government departments, and Members of the House of Representatives. The Presidential Advisory Commission on Holocaust Assets in the United States is composed of 19 members appointed by the President, including private citizens, government representatives, and Members of the House of Representatives and Senate. Private citizens appointed to the Commission must have demonstrated leadership on Holocaust-related issues or in commerce, culture, or education. The Presidential Advisory Commission on Holocaust Assets in the United States appoints advisory panels and a Chairperson selected by the President from among its members. Appointments are made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission with vacancies filled as needed. The Commission's vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings are called by the Chairperson, and thirteen members constitute a quorum. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is required to conduct a thorough study and develop a historical record of assets related to victims of the Holocaust that came into the possession of the Federal Government after January 30, 1933. This includes assets obtained from victims or left unclaimed due to actions taken by certain governments. The Commission is mandated to study and document assets related to Holocaust victims acquired by the Federal Government after January 30, 1933. This includes assets obtained from victims or left unclaimed due to actions by specific governments, such as gold bullion, gems, jewelry, precious metals, and bank accounts in the United States. The Commission is responsible for documenting assets related to Holocaust victims acquired by the Federal Government after January 30, 1933. This includes bank accounts in the United States, domestic financial instruments, insurance policies, real estate, works of art, and cultural objects. The Commission must coordinate its activities with other entities to avoid duplication of efforts. The Commission is tasked with reviewing research on assets related to Holocaust victims acquired by private individuals or entities in the United States after January 30, 1933. This includes assets obtained from victims or left unclaimed due to actions taken by governments. The Commission is reviewing assets related to Holocaust victims acquired in the US after January 30, 1933. Governments included are those associated with the Nazi regime from 1933 to 1945. The Commission will submit a final report with recommendations to the President by December 31, 1999. The Commission may take necessary action and submit reports to the President. The President will then share recommendations with Congress. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. Additionally, the Commission can handle personnel matters. The Commission members do not receive compensation, except for travel expenses as per authorized rates. The Executive Director, Deputy Executive Director, General Counsel, and staff are appointed within 90 days of selecting the Chairperson. The Chairperson of the Commission appoints an executive director, deputy executive director, and general counsel, along with additional personnel as needed. These positions are to be filled without consideration of political affiliation and require necessary security clearances. The executive director serves as the main liaison with other government entities and oversees the administration and duties of the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission appoints an executive director, deputy executive director, and general counsel, along with other personnel. The executive director is responsible for coordinating the review of records and all official activities of the Commission. The Chairperson may set the compensation for these positions without following standard pay rate regulations. The executive director, deputy executive director, and general counsel of the Commission, along with other personnel, have their pay rates limited to level III and IV of the Executive Schedule under title 5, United States Code. Commission employees receive benefits under specific chapters of the code, except for Commission members. The Office of Personnel Management may apply regulations to Commission employees and provide support services. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured by the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates. Staff members must be individuals of integrity and impartiality. Conditional employment may be offered pending security clearance background checks. The Commission can hire individuals on a conditional basis pending security clearances. If a person does not qualify for necessary clearances, their employment will be terminated. Candidates for executive positions will undergo expedited security clearance procedures. The General Services Administration will provide support services for the Commission for 180 days after the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its final report. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission, and meetings should be open to the public whenever possible. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations up to $3,500,000 is allowed for interagency funding of Commission activities under this Act, with funds available until December 31, 1999.
